intro: Phalacrodiscus corsicus, commonly known as the Corsican mallow, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its broad, heart-shaped leaves and showy, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in coastal areas and rocky habitats. Due to its ornamental value, it is cultivated in gardens, though it is considered a rare and endangered species in the wild.
